prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
1. Frequency (Band and Window selections): We propose to use Band 6. We aim at detecting Rayleigh-Jeans tail of blackbody emission of low temperature (10-100 K) cold dust, and hence higher frequencies are in principle advantageous. However, weather condition required to perform at higher frequencies is strict (The estimated maximum time suitable for observation in Band 9 is only 10%, and Band 7 is 40%, according to Table 2 of ALMA Cycle 2 Proposer's Guide). This percentage increases to 70% at Band 6, so we consider that Band 6 is the best option. In addition, we plan to observe 6 sources in total with a moderate exposure rather than an ultra-deep search for only one pulsar in order to understand the universality of the existence of the cold dust disk around the old pulsars. To accomplish this scientific purpose, and also to take into account a competitive situation of ALMA, moderate exposure for each object is required, and therefore we selected Band 6.
As for selection among the 4 recommended observation windows in Band 6, since the center frequency is slightly different (224 GHz to 242 GHz) and the required exposure to achieve the 0.03 mJy sensitivity is different only by 3 minutes (49.57 mins at 224 GHz and 52.63 min at 242 GHz in total including both the calibrator and overhead times). Given this small difference of the required times and the advantage of utilizing higher frequencies for the detection of Rayleigh-Jeans tail of cold dust, we prefer Window 4 (center frequency is 242 GHz). However, since the frequency difference is small and higher frequency observation requires slightly longer observation time, any of the 4 recommended windows is acceptable as long as the 0.03 mJy sensitivity is satisfied within Band 6.
2. Angular Resolution (Array request): We checked optical and near-infrared database and found that there are no bright sources within the radius=8.5 arcsec circular region (shown by a dashed green circle in OT) at the center of the target position. In addition, since the target is located away from the Galactic plane (b=-57.6 deg), the possibility of confusion or contamination by surrounding sources which are not listed in such a database would be very low. According to Table 7.1 of the ALMA Technical Handbook, the angular resolution at Band 6 is 1.67 arcsec at most for the 7 representative array configurations. We can therefore avoid contamination by surrounding sources even at the maximum 1.67 arcsec angular resolution and hence any array configuration is acceptable.
3. Sensitivity: The requested sensitivity is 0.03 mJy at Band 6, which allows us to search for a millimeter counterpart down to 0.09 mJy with 3 sigma detection level. This is almost two orders of magnitude deeper compared to the previous upper limits of ~mJy (Lohmer et al. 2004) and sensitive enough to accomplish our scientific purpose. We estimated the required observation time to achieve this sensitivity including calibrator and overhead times by using OT. As a result, we obtained 52.63 min for Band 6 and Window 4. (Since we propose this high sensitive ALMA survey for the selected 6 pulsars, a total requested time is 5.3 hours.)

1. Frequency (Band and Window selections): We propose to use Band 6. We aim at detecting Rayleigh-Jeans tail of blackbody emission of low temperature (10-100 K) cold dust, and hence higher frequencies are in principle advantageous. However, weather condition required to perform at higher frequencies is strict (The estimated maximum time suitable for observation in Band 9 is only 10%, and Band 7 is 40%, according to Table 2 of ALMA Cycle 2 Proposer's Guide). This percentage increases to 70% at Band 6, so we consider that Band 6 is the best option. In addition, we plan to observe 6 sources in total with a moderate exposure rather than an ultra-deep search for only one pulsar in order to understand the universality of the existence of the cold dust disk around the old pulsars. To accomplish this scientific purpose, and also to take into account a competitive situation of ALMA, moderate exposure for each object is required, and therefore we selected Band 6.
As for selection among the 4 recommended observation windows in Band 6, since the center frequency is slightly different (224 GHz to 242 GHz) and the required exposure to achieve the 0.03 mJy sensitivity is different only by 3 minutes (49.21 mins at 224 GHz and 52.14 min at 242 GHz in total including both the calibrator and overhead times). Given this small difference of the required times and the advantage of utilizing higher frequencies for the detection of Rayleigh-Jeans tail of cold dust, we prefer Window 4 (center frequency is 242 GHz). However, since the frequency difference is small and higher frequency observation requires slightly longer observation time, any of the 4 recommended windows is acceptable as long as the 0.03 mJy sensitivity is satisfied within Band 6.
2. Angular Resolution (Array request): We checked optical and near-infrared database and found that there is one bright source within the radius=8.5 arcsec circular region (shown by a dashed green circle in OT) at the center of the target position. Note that the source is a companion star of the PSR J1023+0038 binary system. In addition, since the target is located away from the Galactic plane (b=45.8 deg), the possibility of confusion or contamination by surrounding sources which are not listed in such a database would be very low. According to Table 7.1 of the ALMA Technical Handbook, the angular resolution at Band 6 is 1.67 arcsec at most for the 7 representative array configurations. We can therefore avoid contamination by surrounding sources even at the maximum 1.67 arcsec angular resolution and hence any array configuration is acceptable.
3. Sensitivity: The requested sensitivity is 0.03 mJy at Band 6, which allows us to search for a millimeter counterpart down to 0.09 mJy with 3 sigma detection level. This is almost two orders of magnitude deeper compared to the previous upper limits of ~mJy (Lohmer et al. 2004) and sensitive enough to accomplish our scientific purpose. We estimated the required observation time to achieve this sensitivity including calibrator and overhead times by using OT. As a result, we obtained 52.14 min for Band 6 and Window 4. (Since we propose this high sensitive ALMA survey for the selected 6 pulsars, a total requested time is 5.3 hours.)

We aim at detecting Rayleigh-Jeans tail of blackbody emission of low temperature (10-100 K) cold dust, and hence higher frequencies are in principle advantageous. As for selection among the 4 recommended observation windows in Band 6, since the center frequency is slightly different (224 GHz to 242 GHz) and the required exposure to achieve the 0.03 mJy sensitivity is different only by 3 minutes (50.50 mins at 224 GHz and 53.89 min at 242 GHz in total including both the calibrator and overhead times). Given this small difference of the required times and the advantage of utilizing higher frequencies for the detection of Rayleigh-Jeans tail of cold dust, we prefer Window 4 (center frequency is 242 GHz). However, since the frequency difference is small and higher frequency observation requires slightly longer observation time, any of the 4 recommended windows is acceptable as long as the 0.03 mJy sensitivity is satisfied within Band 6.

In addition, since the target is located away from the Galactic plane (b=75.4 deg), the possibility of confusion or contamination by surrounding sources which are not listed in such a database would be very low. According to Table 7.1 of the ALMA Technical Handbook, the angular resolution at Band 6 is 1.67 arcsec at most for the 7 representative array configurations. We can therefore avoid contamination by surrounding sources even at the maximum 1.67 arcsec angular resolution and hence any array configuration is acceptable.

1. Frequency (Band and Window selections): We propose to use Band 6. We aim at detecting Rayleigh-Jeans tail of blackbody emission of low temperature (10-100 K) cold dust, and hence higher frequencies are in principle advantageous. As for selection among the 4 recommended observation windows in Band 6, since the center frequency is slightly different (224 GHz to 242 GHz) and the required exposure to achieve the 0.03 mJy sensitivity is different only by 3 minutes (48.59 mins at 224 GHz and 51.27 min at 242 GHz in total including both the calibrator and overhead times). Given this small difference of the required times and the advantage of utilizing higher frequencies for the detection of Rayleigh-Jeans tail of cold dust, we prefer Window 4 (center frequency is 242 GHz). However, since the frequency difference is small and higher frequency observation requires slightly longer observation time, any of the 4 recommended windows is acceptable as long as the 0.03 mJy sensitivity is satisfied within Band 6.
2. Angular Resolution (Array request): We checked optical and near-infrared database and found that there are no bright sources within the radius=8.5 arcsec circular region (shown by a dashed green circle in OT) at the center of the target position. In addition, since the target is located away from the Galactic plane (b=9.2 deg), the possibility of confusion or contamination by surrounding sources which are not listed in such a database would be very low. According to Table 7.1 of the ALMA Technical Handbook, the angular resolution at Band 6 is 1.67 arcsec at most for the 7 representative array configurations. We can therefore avoid contamination by surrounding sources even at the maximum 1.67 arcsec angular resolution and hence any array configuration is acceptable.
3. Sensitivity: The requested sensitivity is 0.03 mJy at Band 6, which allows us to search for a millimeter counterpart down to 0.09 mJy with 3 sigma detection level. This is almost two orders of magnitude deeper compared to the previous upper limits of ~mJy (Lohmer et al. 2004) and sensitive enough to accomplish our scientific purpose. We estimated the required observation time to achieve this sensitivity including calibrator and overhead times by using OT. As a result, we obtained 51.27 min for Band 6 and Window 4. (Since we propose this high sensitive ALMA survey for the selected 6 pulsars, a total requested time is 5.3 hours.)

1. Frequency (Band and Window selections): We propose to use Band 6. We aim at detecting Rayleigh-Jeans tail of blackbody emission of low temperature (10-100 K) cold dust, and hence higher frequencies are in principle advantageous. However, weather condition required to perform at higher frequencies is strict (The estimated maximum time suitable for observation in Band 9 is only 10%, and Band 7 is 40%, according to Table 2 of ALMA Cycle 2 Proposer's Guide). This percentage increases to 70% at Band 6, so we consider that Band 6 is the best option. In addition, we plan to observe 6 sources in total with a moderate exposure rather than an ultra-deep search for only one pulsar in order to understand the universality of the existence of the cold dust disk around the old pulsars. To accomplish this scientific purpose, and also to take into account a competitive situation of ALMA, moderate exposure for each object is required, and therefore we selected Band 6.
As for selection among the 4 recommended observation windows in Band 6, since the center frequency is slightly different (224 GHz to 242 GHz) and the required exposure to achieve the 0.03 mJy sensitivity is different only by 7 minutes (52.14 mins at 224 GHz and 58.79 min at 242 GHz in total including both the calibrator and overhead times). Given this small difference of the required times and the advantage of utilizing higher frequencies for the detection of Rayleigh-Jeans tail of cold dust, we prefer Window 4 (center frequency is 242 GHz). However, since the frequency difference is small and higher frequency observation requires slightly longer observation time, any of the 4 recommended windows is acceptable as long as the 0.03 mJy sensitivity is satisfied within Band 6.
2. Angular Resolution (Array request): We checked optical and near-infrared database and found that there is one bright source at ~4 arcsec away from the target position. In addition, since the target is located at the Galactic plane (b=-0.3 deg), we are a little worried about confusion or contamination by surrounding sources. Hence, we would like to set the required angular resolution of <0.61 arcsec, namely except the configurations of C34-1 and C34-2. Such a compact configuration also causes shadowing due to the low elevation angle of the source (Figure 7.3 of ALMA Cycle2 Technical Handbook). We therefore request array configurations except C34-1 and C34-2.
3. Sensitivity: The requested sensitivity is 0.03 mJy at Band 6, which allows us to search for a millimeter counterpart down to 0.09 mJy with 3 sigma detection level. This is almost two orders of magnitude deeper compared to the previous upper limits of ~mJy (Lohmer et al. 2004) and sensitive enough to accomplish our scientific purpose. We estimated the required observation time to achieve this sensitivity including calibrator and overhead times by using OT. As a result, we obtained 58.79 min for Band 6 and Window 4. (Since we propose this high sensitive ALMA survey for the selected 6 pulsars, a total requested time is 5.3 hours.)

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Many pieces of indirect evidence as well as theoretical studies have expected the existence of disks around isolated pulsars. Taking advantage of ALMAs great sensitivity, we propose millimeter imaging of 6 old pulsar systems, reasonably selected from the current pulsar catalog. Detection of surrounding cold dust would provide direct evidence for the expectation, and imply that in general post main-sequence stars would have planetary and disk systems similar to that around normal stars, although formation mechanisms are different.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Hiroshima Astrophysical Science Center, Hiroshima University

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Shanghai Astronomical Observatory, Chinese Academy of Sciences
The Institute of Space and Astronautical Science, Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency
